timeline.bodyText:
Hi, is that possible to get the datatype of the sensor?
As IoTDB compresses int/long/float/double better than text, and in some applications, users know what data type their data is.
By the way, it is recommended that using CompressionType.SNAPPY by default.
timeline.author: jixuan1989

replies.bodyText: Good idea, I will update later.
replies.author: vesense

timeline.bodyText:
In many applications, when a monitored device sends data to the server, it does not just send one data point.
Instead, it sends a "row", i.e., several measurements and their values. (And in some applications, they even sends data with several timestamps, but it is not very common.)
As far as I know, a device may have more than 100 measurements in the industrial applications. In this case, splitting a "row" into many Events may burden Flink as well as IoTDB (because there are too many small TCP packets).
How do you think?
timeline.author: jixuan1989

timeline.bodyText: Can we remove this flag as I think batchSize can express the same semantics  with （batchSize+batchFlushOnCheckpoint)?
timeline.author: sunjincheng121

replies.bodyText:
Agree. It is a little strange.
If batchFlushOnCheckpoint == false, then the data will never be written into IoTDB...
replies.author: jixuan1989

replies.bodyText:
batchFlushOnCheckpoint is the switch for batch inserting.
False by default, users can change by invoking withBatchFlushOnCheckpoint(true)
There are two parameters related to batch.

batch size (iotDBSink.withBatchSize(10))
checkpoint interval (timer) (env.enableCheckpointing(3000))

if `batchFlushOnCheckpoint` == true
    if batchList >= batch size || checkpoint interval arises (`snapshotState`)
        then session.insertInBatch
    else 
        add to batchList
else
    session.insert
replies.author: vesense

replies.bodyText:
I mean that only  batchList is enough. By default batchList=0 means  we insert the data immediately(batchFlushOnCheckpoint==true), and if batchList>0 means we will insert the data in batch.  User do not need config the batchFlushOnCheckpoint, the  isCheckpointingEnabled can help us make the decision of whether buffered the data is required.
What do you think?
replies.author: sunjincheng121

replies.bodyText:
When a user uses such a module, two things that he/she may consider:

I want to reduce the network cost, therefore I will write data until I collect 1000 data points.
However, if some device generates data too rarely, e.g., in 0.01Hz (i.e., generates a data point per 100 seconds),and if I have to wait for 1000 data points coming, I have to want for about 100,000 seconds. So, I want that, if I have buffered data for 3 seconds and the buffer is not full, I will send these data to IoTDB.

That is to say, batchList is for setting the buffer size, and enableCheckpointing( time interval) is for setting the acceptable latency.
replies.author: jixuan1989

replies.bodyText:
Thanks @sunjincheng121 and @jixuan1989 for your advices.
I decided to optimize the relevant logic to avoid user harassment.

use batchsize as the batch switch(by default batchList=0  insert the data immediately, and if batchList>0  insert the data in batch)
use a new timer instead of checkpointing to ensure the data flush SLA.

These changes will be committed later.
replies.author: vesense

timeline.author: sunjincheng121

replies.bodyText: This is the default batch size. Users can change by invoking withBatchSize.
replies.author: vesense

timeline.bodyText: If the batch size > 0, then we need a timer for flush the buffer data.
timeline.author: sunjincheng121

replies.bodyText: The timer here is checkpoint interval.
replies.author: vesense

replies.bodyText:
Some times checkpoint interval is pretty long, even may 10min or more. and the  checkpoint is ensure do not miss data when checkpointing, but not ensure the SLA(such as delayed), So in this case it's better to have opportunity to set timer for flush data.
What do you think?
replies.author: sunjincheng121

replies.bodyText:
Looks similar but different.MeasurementSchema  describes a measurement's information registered in FileSchema for ts file serializing and deserializing.  TimeseriesOption  describes a timeseries options information for Flink job configuration.
